attributes.title: Physical stock count
attributes.description:
·       A physical inventory count was conducted on 08 April 2025 to verify the accuracy of inventory by comparing the physically counted quantity with those of SAP system and to determine if branch inventory controls were sufficient to minimize risks.

·       It was noted that there were a few discrepancies in the raw materials and finished products as seen

ü  Bread stock had +4.75 pieces

ü  Packing materials had +3290 pieces

ü  Crates had -76 pieces.

ü  White flour and brown flour had -7.757 kgs and +5.595 Kgs respectively

ü  Other raw materials had insignificant variations as detailed in the summary.

Table 1:Stock count summary.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should strengthen stock controls to minimize variations noted especially on polybags by conducting regular counts.

·       The branch management should minimize opening balances in crates as this poses a higher risk of loss of crates and sales team should regularly visit routes to check accuracy of the opening crates balances.

Recoveries to be done on the lost crates.
attributes.effect: ·   The discrepancies between the book stock and physical stock indicate potential control weaknesses in stock management especially crates movementSignificant positive variations in polybags indicates the possibility of excess packaging of polybags sachets.

value:
·       I will follow up on the root cause of positive variations in polybags,

·       Differences in BOM in barrel, Grande and Ct varieties resulted in negative variance in white flour.Crates deductions’ have been raised and approved for recovery.

·       Manager should control the variations by conducting daily stocks to check to determine the cause of significant positive variations in polybags.Crates deductions’ have been raised and approved for recovery.

·       In the prior Audit dated 07/03/2025, the following variances were noted:

ü  Bread stock had a variance of -26 pieces.

ü  Polybags had +1608 pieces

ü  White flour was -2.33 Kgs and brown flour was +3.04 kgs.

ü  Wheat bran was +1.59Kgs.

ü  Other raw materials had insignificant variance.Crates had nil variations.
Current

attributes.title: Bread Weights
attributes.description:
·       A spot check on packed bread ready to be supplied to the markets was done on 08 April 2025 to determine if they met the standard weights as per the KEBS requirements.

·       Underweights were noted across all the sampled varieties as seen below:

ü  400g CTW had 44% underweights.

ü  600 CTW had 7% underweight

ü  800 CTW had 17% underweight.

ü  200g Mini loaf had 43% underweight

ü  400 g Long had 20% underweight.

·       Below is the detailed summary of the audit findings.

Table 2:Bread weight Check.
attributes.recommendation: ·    Branch management should ensure correct production procedures are followed to ensure product quality is not compromised.Branch management should also conduct random spot checks on dough weight and packed bread to ensure bread of correct weight is supplied to the market.
attributes.effect:
·       Underweights and overweight’s noted indicates lapses production process flow.

·       Underweights exposes the company to penalties for non-compliance and may damage brand reputation if underweights are found out by KEBS officials.Underweights also deny the customer value for their money.

value: We will do random spot checks especially on dough weight to minimise cases of underweights.
The manager is advised to do random spot checks especially on dough weight and as operation I will be doing frequent checks to minimise cases of underweights

·       In the prior audit dated 07th March 2025, it was noted that underweights in packed breads were as follows;    

ü  400g 200 ML had 60%

ü  600g CT and butter had 60% and 12% respectively.

ü  800 CTW and Butter had 56% and 11% respectively.

ü  400g Long, 400 CTW and 400 BW had 17%,29% and 13 % respectively.

400g Dough weight for unit I and II respectively had 45% and 39% respectively.
Current
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Damages
attributes.description:
·       A review of Production and market damages was done for a period of 39 days from 1March 2025-08 April 2025 to assess whether they were within the allowable limits of 0.2% of total production 0.5% of total sales respectively.

·       It was noted that production damages were at 0.24% of total production which was above the allowable threshold of 0.2% with a cost implication of Kshs.18,721.735 while market damages were at 0.54% of total sales exclusive of supermarket returns which was above the allowable limit of 0.5% with a cost implication of Kshs 17,943.68.

·       Below is a detailed summary of the audit findings:

Table 3:Production Damages.

N/B: The above analysis is exclusive of 331 pieces of Oven damages.

Table 4:Market Damages.
attributes.recommendation: To adhere to the set quality control procures within the production process to ensure bread of good quality is produced thus minimizing cases of underweights.
attributes.effect: Production and market damages exceeded the allowable limits by 0.04% and 0.04% respectively with a cumulative extra cost of Kshs (18,721.74+17,943.68) =36,665.42.

value: Excess damages were as result of the quality of flour used for production Atta which produces excess damages, but we will put more controls.
Excess damages were as result of the quality of flour used for production Atta which produces excess damages, but we will put more controls.

·       During the prior audit dated 07th March 2025, it was found that;        

ü  Production bread damages were averaging at 0.22% of the production.Market damages stood at 0.51% of the sales
Current

attributes.title: Mixing Chart analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for a period of 39 days from 1 March 2025-08 February 2025 was done with the aim of determining if Average yield was as per the set Branch BOM, if Utto consumption was at a ratio of 1:1,if there were any cases of remixes and to determine if Branch production capacity was being fully utilized.

·       It was noted that:

ü  Average yield was at 192.73.

ü  Utto consumption stood at 100%

ü  Average daily production was at 117.49 bags

ü  Branch production capacity was at 71.20% of the target of 165 bags.

ü  No Cases of remixes were noted for the period under review.

Table 5:Mixing Chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation: The sales team should put more efforts to acquire new customers, ensuring optimal utilization of the branch's production capacity.
attributes.effect: ·       The branch production capacity is not fully utilized meaning there is need for further improvement.No remixes implies that product quality is being achieved.

value: Production capacity is affected by low sales hence we sometimes run one unit, but we have received new tins for 400g hence we will be producing more CTW for transfers to Dandora branches.
Production capacity is affected by low sales hence we sometimes run one unit, but we have received new tins for 400g hence we will be producing more CTW for transfers to Dandora branches.

·       In the prior audit, dated 7th March 2025, it was noted that.

ü  Average yield was at 192.78 loaves per bag,

ü  Utto consumption was at 100%,

ü  Average production was at 119.57 bags per day representing 72.69% of the set target of 164 bags.

ü  No cases of remixes were noted.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Production efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was done for a period of 39 days from 1 March 2025-8 March 2025 to determine if production workers allocation was done as per the shift targets ensuring full utilization of production workers by achieving the KPI of 4.3 per production worker.

·       It was noted that production efficiency was at 4.23 bags per production worker which was below the KPI of 4.3 bags ,16 extra workers were hired with an extra cost of Kshs 17,385.6.

·       Below is the detailed summary of the findings:

Table 6:Production Efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch management should ensure allocation of workers is done as per the shift targets to ensure no extra workers are hired.
attributes.effect: Production workers were underutilized,16 extra workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs 17,385.60.

value: The major cause affecting production efficiency is shift cuts, we have currently received new 400g tins hence we are expecting to run full capacity for transfers to Dandora.
The major cause affecting production efficiency is shift cuts, we have currently received new 400g tins hence we are expecting to run full capacity for transfers to Dandora.
·       In the prior audit dated 7th March 2025 it was noted that:Production efficiency was 4.23 Bags per production worker.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Packing efficiency.
attributes.description:
·       Packing efficiency for the period of 39 days from 1March 2025-08April 2025 was done with an aim of determining if the packers hired were achieving the set average packing efficiency of 97 crates per packer.

·       Packing efficiency stood at 94.95 crates which was below the standard of 97 crates per packer, the branch hired extra 14 workers with a cost implication of Kshs. 12,768.

·       The table below illustrates the findings; -
attributes.recommendation: ·       Management should ensure hiring of workers is done as per the prior shift actual target to minimise cases of extra workers hired.The branch management should also tighten supervision of packers to ensure they are achieving their KPI
attributes.effect: Packers did not achieve their KPI of 97 crates ,14 extra workers were hired leading to an extra cost of Kshs12,768.

value: There is improvement from previous audits, more improvement is expected.
There is improvement from previous audits, more improvement is expected.
In the prior audit, the finding revealed that the average slicing efficiency was 92 crates per slicer,22 extra workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.18,240.
Current

attributes.title: Minishop
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted at the mini shop on March 8th, 2025, to assess whether operations were being carried out in line with the established standards and to determine if expected sales agreed with the cash balances in the Mpesa till number.

·       The mini shop's expected sales were arrived from the total daily loadings less bread balances at the time of stock. No variations were noted however there were customer advance payments worth Kshs 901.

·       The table below illustrates the findings.
attributes.recommendation: Mini shop controls are working effectively however customer advance payments should be discouraged. Mini shop salesperson should inform customers to pay only upon receipt of Bread.
attributes.effect: The presence of payments from other routes in the mini shop Mpesa till could create confusion in financial records, making it difficult to track accurate revenue for each sales point.

value: Mini shop controls to be maintained.
Mini shop controls to be maintained.
In the prior audit, the findings showed that there was a positive of Kshs.36,846.6.
Current

attributes.title: Generator fuel consumption
attributes.description:
·       Generator fuel consumption was done for a period of March 2025 to determine if fuel consumption was within the standards range in comparison with prior months.

·       Generator fuel consumption was at 26.72 L/H for unit one and 21.82 L/H for unit 2 this was within the range as detailed below:

Table 7:Generator fuel consumption unit one.

Table 8:Generator fuel consumption Unit 2.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should uphold the existing controls and ensure proper calibration is conducted to facilitate accurate reconciliation between the two records.
attributes.effect: The fuel consumption was within range.

value: Generator fuel consumption is within range to be maintained.
Generator fuel consumption is within range to be maintained.
In the prior audit, the findings revealed that the consumption rate stood for unit one generator was at 23.61 litres per hour while unit two generator consumed 21.09 litres per hour.
Current

attributes.title: Mileage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       Analysis of fuel consumption was done for a period of March,2025 to assess, whether the standard mileage set for each vehicle was being met and that fuel was allocated to each vehicle as per the standard rate and kilometres covered.

·       It was noted that fuel consumption was within range except one vehicle supplying route Tala which had consumed extra 7 Litres as detailed below in Appendix 1 below:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure fuel allocation is done as per standard rate for each motor vehicle.
attributes.effect: The company incurred extra costs on vehicles that consumed more fuel.

value: I will check and ensure fuel is issued as per the kilometres covered.
Manager to check and ensure fuel is issued as per the kilometres covered.

In the prior audit, it was noted dated 7th March 2025, it was noted that fuel consumption was within the standards rates however Wote motor vehicle KDQ 559Z had fualty speedometer although the issue had been communicated to be resolved. Other fleet consumption
Current

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted in the cash office was done on 8 April 2025 to verify that the cash on hand matched the cash flow balance and to assess the effectiveness of the existing cash control measures.

·       All cash was properly accounted for, as outlined below:

Table 9:Cash verification.
attributes.recommendation: Continue enforcing strict cash handling policies and regular reconciliations to uphold accuracy and accountability.
attributes.effect: The proper accounting of all cash indicates that the existing cash control procedures are effective in minimize risks.

value: ·       Cash controls to be maintained
·       Cash controls to be maintained
In a previous audit, it was observed that all cash was fully accounted for with a variation of Kshs -1.
Current

attributes.title: Debtors’ analysis.
attributes.description:
·       A review of debtors balances as of 9 April 2025 was done to determine if there were instances of long outstanding debts by determining the credit worthiness of customers, assessing if the internal controls over credit management, invoicing, collection are functioning effectively and to assess the level of risk associated outstanding receivables.

·       It was noted that the branch had a total of 1,365,134.02 which were secured by security deposits, Supa point and extra cent. We also noted that there were a few dormant customers worth Kshs 654,278 which were yet to be recovered from the security deposits.

·       A detailed analysis of the balances is illustrated below in Appendix 2 below:
attributes.recommendation: The branch management is recommended to ensure the outstanding debtors balances are followed up for payments.
attributes.effect: ·       The company is exposed to risk of losing its revenue in case customers and institutions highlighted in green won’t be able to pay.

value: Daily follow up will be done to ensure debtors are cleared.
Daily follow up will be done to ensure debtors are cleared.

In the prior audit dated 7th March 2025, the audit identified cases of misappropriation of client funds by turnboys who lacked sufficient security, exposing the branch to potential financial loss. It was also noted of dormant accounts which were not sufficiently secured thus requiring sales representative continued follow up.The outstanding debt exclusive of prepayments was KES 1,401,286.80 primarily secured through security deposits, extra cents, Supa Points and well-performing clients with credit limits
